message: So if you're interested -- and we'll definitely keep this going here for now -- but if you're interested in Dramatica and want to see if we can make the community even better, please head over to http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/34364/dramatica-theory-of-story?referrer=QqN4FKzLhgw9rk9eRLhWhQ2 and sign up.

We need at least 60 followers before we can get out of the Definition phase. We only have 46 here, and that took 6 months to build, so I'm not anticipating this happening any time soon. But please add your name if interested. Also, look around at other Q&A sites built on the same engine there and see if you think it would be a good thing to discuss Dramatica.

In my never-ending quest to find greater and greater tools for enriching the Dramatica community, I've come across a Q&A Site service built on the StackOverflow engine (which you may have come across in your travels across the internet from time-to-time). With specific tools and design that encourage expert responses, it's my feeling that this could be a good "upgrade" from Convore. Comments or responses can be upvoted or downvoted depending on the appropriateness of the answer, making it easier for those in search of help to get the information they need and quickly return to their writing. Tagging and other tools for organizing the responses and discussions make this a good tool for increasing one's knowledge of the theory.

If you do sign up, please add a possible sample question, or even a question you think would NOT be appropriate for discussion there. During this setup phase there needs to be detailed conversation about what we should be talking about and how we can better help those new to the theory who want to improve their writing.
The more activity over there, the quicker we can get it setup. Thanks, and happy writing!
One last thing, be sure to upvote or downvote the questions as you see fit (you can't work your own), that way we can get a feel for what people are interested in discussing.

I know some people hold their stuff pretty close and wouldn't feel comfortable, but others who are learning this might find it invaluable to have that type of interactive feedback.
